text: Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362

Landslides in the North Atlantic and its adjacent seas:
an analysis of their morphology, setting and behaviour
V. Hqhnerbach*, D.G. Masson,
partners of the COSTA-Project
Southampton Oceanography Centre, Waterfront Campus, European Way, Southampton SO14 3ZH, United Kingdom
Accepted 30 September 2004
Abstract

A unique and comprehensive collection of submarine landslide data from different tectonic environments in the North
Atlantic, based on published literature and industry sources, is analysed in order to establish possible relationships between
landslide parameters and evaluate their potential importance. Slope failures in the western North Atlantic appear to be more
frequent, and apart from a few huge failure complexes, on average smaller than those found in the eastern North Atlantic. On
the other hand, failures tend to occur on lower slopes in the eastern North Atlantic. This trend could be used to conclude
information about the sediment strata of the landslides in these two areas; long slides seem to consist of softer, more fluid,
material, whereas short failures might contain of more stiff sediments. It is also found that a majority of failures on both sides of
the Atlantic are generated in a water depth window between 1000 and 1300 m, bringing internal waves and/or gas hydrates into
play as possible contributing factors. Failures in fjords are generally influenced and limited by the geometry of the environment
they occur in.
D 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: slope failures; statistics; database; North Atlantic; COSTA project
1. Introduction

Submarine slope failure is known from many
different environments all over the world. It is one
of the most important mechanisms in shaping

* Corresponding author. Tel.: +44 23 8059 6555; fax: +44 23
8059 6554.
E-mail addresses: vhh@soc.soton.ac.uk (V. Hqhnerbach)8
dgm@soc.soton.ac.uk (D.G. Masson).

0025-3227/$ - see front matter D 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
doi:10.1016/j.margeo.2004.10.013
www.elsevier.com/locate/margeo

continental margins, transporting vast quantities of
sediment downslope. During the last two decades
several attempts have been made to group, summarise
and analyse some of these mass failures (Schwarz,
1982; Booth et al., 1993; Hampton et al., 1996; Dade
and Huppert, 1998; McAdoo et al., 2000). This paper
compares submarine landslides from different tectonic
environments (fjords, volcanic islands, active and
passive continental margins), concentrating on slope
failure data from the North Atlantic and adjacent seas.

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
344

It includes most of the previously published data sets,
plus new literature and additional commercial land-
slide information, much of which is not publicly
available, to create a unique compilation collated
during the Continental Slope Stability (COSTA)
project.
The aim of this analysis is to describe and
determine the parameters, such as dimensions (length,
width, runout distance, thicknesses), failure area and
volume, slope angle and headscarp height, that might
be of greatest importance in controlling the processes
driving slope failure in different environments. The
possible relationship between combinations of certain
parameters was also of special interest. The overview
figure (Fig. 1) shows where slope failures were
identified and reported, either by project partners or
in the literature. For ease of reference, slope failures in
the Mediterranean, Baltic and Black Sea will be
grouped and referred to as eastern North Atlantic. The

Fig. 1. Overview map of slope failures in the western and eastern North Atlantic including adjacent seas (Mediterranean, Black Sea, Baltic
Seas), fjords of Norway and eastern Canada and failures in other limited/confined areas. Each point represents a single failure or slope failure
complex either reported in literature or supplied through project partner data. In cases where a landslide extends over a larger area, the central
position between headwall and toe of deposit is shown. Contour lines of 1000 and 3000 m are shown in grey. Figure was produced with GMT
software (Wessel and Smith, 1991).

group dFjords and othersT includes the fjords in
Norway and eastern Canada as well as landslides in
special limited areas, such as harbours and tidal flats.
2. Selection of data, quality control and limitations

At the beginning of the project, it was decided to
set up a template with specially selected parameters
(Fig. 2). Project partners were then asked for
contributions towards the database. In addition to
these data provided by partners, the published
literature was thoroughly searched for information
and data that could be entered into the template. It
became evident from early in the project that many
database entries would be fragmentary as, when
compared with the requirements of the database, data
from the literature were often incomplete. In a few
cases, it was possible to estimate lacking dareaT and

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
345

Fig. 2. COSTA slope failure data template showing one example from the Canary Islands and its parameters collated. Where possible, the
authors of the sources were asked to do a data quality assessment on the data, differentiating between data based on good and comprehensive
information, on limited information (or where the data set cannot be interpreted with certainty), or on minimal information.

dvolumeT data entries from given dlengthT, dwidthT and
dthickness of slope failureT parameters.
In order to evaluate the database entries, contrib-
utors were asked to undertake a quality control
showing how good or reliable their data is. A similar
approach was applied to data from the literature taking
into account when the survey was done and the
equipment used at that time. As an example, seafloor
data of failures, which were collected some 30 or 40

years ago, is clearly likely to be inferior in terms of
resolution, positioning accuracy and processing tech-
niques than data obtained with the latest high-
resolution sidescan, seismics or multibeam bathyme-
try. It has to be recognised that the coverage of slope
failures detected and surveyed in the North Atlantic is
not necessarily representative as some areas have been
investigated in greater detail than others, e.g. due to
economic interests. For example, mapping of the

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
346

entire economic zone of the Eastern US continental
margin has revealed many different slope failures and
helped to establish a good understanding of land-
sliding on this particular margin (Lee et al., 1993). By
comparison, data coverage on the eastern North
Atlantic margin is much less complete. One possible
result of this is that smaller slope failures may remain
undetected in areas with a less dense survey grid.
Where data about dimensions of slope failure were
presented as a range instead of a single value, the
mean value of this range was chosen. In cases where
only minimum values were known, these were
increased by 70%, in order to estimate the mean
value. Where maximum values were stated, a similar
dcorrection factorT of 25% was subtracted. These
percentages were calculated from all ranges of all
parameters available, looking at the change in value
necessary to reach the mean from both ends of the
range. The authors are aware that these dcorrection
factorsT are approximations, and they were used with
caution.
3. Statistical analysis and results

In total, nearly 300 slope failures have been
identified of which more than 260 have been selected
and entered into the database. The database itself is, in
parts, very incomplete. Therefore, only the parameters
most commonly available, such as dimensions
(length, width, area and volume), slope angle (in
source and deposition area), total height (from top of
the headwall to toe of deposit), headwall height and
water depth have been analysed in detail. To allow
comparison of slope failures from different settings,
the catalogued landslides have been split into four
categories: the open continental slope (separated into
eastern and western North Atlantic), fjords and
volcanic islands. The eastern and western North
Atlantic margins were treated separately because
initial visual analysis of the data suggested significant
differences in certain parameters (e.g., failure size and
slope angles) between the two areas. Because exam-
ples of landslides from around the Canary Islands
were insufficient for statistical analysis some data
from volcanic island landslides on Hawaii were
included for the creation of overview histograms.
However, volcanic island data were neither included

in scatter plots, nor in correlation tables as the
numbers valid parameter pairs are not sufficient.
The median values (based on the total number of
cases shown) of the catalogued parameters for open
continental slopes (separated into western and eastern
North Atlantic) and fjords are compiled in Table 1,
defining the dtypicalT slope failure in each of the

Note that the size parameters (area, volume etc.) were estimated
independently from the data entries available, and therefore cannot
always be related arithmetically.

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
347

different environments. A table for a dtypicalT land-
slide on volcanic islands could not be established due
to too few data. Median values are used, rather than
means, because of the extreme asymmetrical distribu-
tion of some parameters, see histograms in Figs. 3–6.
This skewed distribution results in the mean being
controlled by a few exceptionally large landslides,
while the median better describes a dtypicalT landslide.
For example, the mean area of an individual slope
failure on the western North Atlantic margin is 325
km2, averaged over 126 measurements. If the four
largest values, ranging from N1000 to 25,000 km2 are
removed, the mean decreases to 38.6 km2, showing
that the mean is totally dominated by the few very
large events. By comparison, the median is only 9
km2, showing that most landslides on this margin are
actually quite small.
Detailed histograms for the individual parameters,
again subdivided into eastern and western North
Atlantic continental margins, fjords and volcanic
islands, are shown in Figs. 3–6, and are described
below.

3.1. Open continental margin—western North Atlantic
(Fig. 3)

On open continental margins in the western North
Atlantic, the median slope angle on which landslides
have occurred is 58. The minimum and maximum
values range from b18 to about 248 with the steeper
slopes mainly associated with submarine canyons.
The median water depth of failure headwalls is 1160
m. Median failure dimensions are as follows: length
3.5 km, width 2.25 km, area 9 km2 and volume 1.4
km3. However, the ranges for these dimensions are
enormous. For example, some events are only a few
hundred metres long, others several hundreds of
kilometres. The area covered by individual failure
ranges from 0.1 up to 25,000 km2.
The database contains insufficient entries to allow
calculation of the median height of a headwall of
western North Atlantic landslides; the median thick-
ness of the deposit is around 35 m. Not enough data is
available to give a value for the thickness of the failed
section, but the sparse data available indicate that it
could be up to 2–3 times the deposit thickness for a
small, simple failure and up to more than 10 times for
a multifailure complex. The total height of slope

failures—from the top of the headwall to the toe of the
deposit—can in extreme cases reach up to 4100 m for
a multiple landslide or landslide complex, but in most
cases is more typically 150–300 m.

3.2. Open continental margin—eastern North Atlantic
(Fig. 4)

On open continental margins in the eastern North
Atlantic, the median slope angle on which landslides
have occurred is 38. All but one landslide occurred on
slopes of b158, with one example (actually located in
the Mediterranean) on a slope close to 308. The single
example on the high slope is the 1979 Nice landslide
(Klaucke and Cochonat, 1999; Klaucke et al., 1999).
This is atypical of eastern North Atlantic landslides in
that it is the only event that occurred on an area of
canyoned slope, its headwall is located in very
shallow water, and it may have been triggered by
man’s activity. The median water depth of failure
headwalls in the eastern North Atlantic is 1175 m.
Median failure dimensions are as follows: length
117.5 km, width 22.5 km, area 1550 km2 and volume
30 km3. As with the western North Atlantic, the
ranges for these dimensions are enormous. For
example, the area covered by individual failure ranges
from 16 up to 112,000 km2.
The median height of the headwall is 47.5 m; the
thickness of the deposit is around 125 m, while the
failed section is 162.5 m thick. The total height of
mass failures—from the top of the headwall to the toe
of the deposit—can in extreme cases reach up to 3400
m for a multiple landslide or landslide complex, but in
most cases is more typically 1100–1500 m.
3.3. Fjords and others (Fig. 5)

The median slope angle in the source area of
landslides in fjords is 5.58 with a range from b28 up to
a maximum of 208. The median water depth is 15 m,
ranging from sea level to a depth of 550 m. The
dimensions of landslides in fjords are limited by the
morphology and geometry of the fjord (Syvitski et al.,
1987). These circumstances are reflected in the
relatively small range of values for length, width,
area coverage, volume, and headwall height. The
median landslide is about 1.5 km long and 0.5 km
wide, covers an area of 0.5 km2 and has a volume of

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
348

about 0.04 km3. Extreme cases can exceed these
values more than 10-fold. The height of the headwall
created by a typical landslide is around 20 m, which is
in most cases comparable with the thickness of the

Fig. 3. Histograms of slope failure parameters for events in the western North Atlantic. The vertical axis in the graphs shows the number of
failures; n is the total number of failures represented in each histogram. When extreme values were excluded (to increase the interpretability of
the histogram), this is mentioned in the graph. The solid black lines represent normal distributions with the same mean and standard deviation as
the parameter presented in each histogram.

failed sediment. In comparison, the thickness of the
deposit is up to a factor of 10 times smaller (median 2
m), suggesting that these failures might have a
disintegrative behaviour.

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
349
Fig. 3 (continued).
3.4. Volcanic islands (Fig. 6)

The results of the statistical analysis of land-
slides on volcanic island slopes have to be taken
with great care, as the number of cases is small
and for most cases only very few parameters are
available.
In
many
cases,
failures
started
as
subaerial avalanches, developing into or initiating
debris
flows
and
sometimes
turbidity
currents
travelling for hundreds of kilometres, making it
difficult to define the dimensions (Moore et al.,
1989; Masson et al., 1998, 2002; Gee et al.,
1999). However, it can still be shown that the
length and width of landslides on volcanic island
slopes can vary from a few kilometres to several
hundred kilometres. The area covered by such a
landslide can reach a few thousand square kilo-
metres
and
the
volume
several
hundred
cubic
kilometres. Most of the failures on volcanic islands

appear to be related to volcanic/tectonic activity
such as magma dykes intruding into the island
flanks (Masson et al., 2002; Elsworth and Voight,
1995).
4. Discussion
4.1. Distribution of parameter values

Most of the histograms of the slide parameters
are highly skewed towards very low values, with a
few scattered high values (Figs. 3–6). Note, that
this
skewness
is
actually
more
extreme
than
depicted in Figs. 3–6, because a few of the larger
values
have
been
omitted
from
these
plots
to
allow trends in the bulk of the data to be mean-
ingfully represented in the histograms (see figure
captions). This type of distribution is very common

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
350

in geological environments (Davis, 1986). The
reason for the scatter of the data is that the
landslides did not all happen in the same environ-
ment under the same boundary conditions (Hampton
et al., 1996).

Fig. 4. Histograms of slope failure parameters for events in the eastern North Atlantic and adjacent seas. The vertical axis in the graphs shows
the number of failures; n is the total number of failures represented in each histogram. When extreme values were excluded (to increase the
interpretability of the histogram), this is mentioned in the graph. The solid black lines represent normal distributions with the same mean and
standard deviation as the parameter presented in each histogram.

4.2. Comparison of western and eastern North
Atlantic margins

There are some clear differences in landslide
parameters between the western and eastern North

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
351
Fig. 4 (continued).

Atlantic slopes. For example, the median values for
the slope angle in areas affected by landslides in the
western North Atlantic is 4.58, but in the eastern North
Atlantic only 2.28 (Table 1). Landslides appear to be
both significantly smaller and much more numerous
in the western North Atlantic (Figs. 3, 4). It is
tempting to suggest that this is due to a survey bias,

with greater survey effort having been made in the
western North Atlantic (Booth et al., 1993; McAdoo
et al., 2000). However, enough of the eastern North
Atlantic margin has been surveyed in detail (Bugge et
al., 1987; Jansen et al., 1987; Haflidason et al., 1997;
Urgeles et al., 1997; Masson et al., 1998; Laberg and
Vorren, 2000; Laberg et al., 2000; Weaver et al., 2000;

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
352

Wynn et al., 2000; Kuijpers et al., 2001; Lastras et al.,
2002) to indicate that abundant small failures are not
widespread on this side of the Atlantic, and that the
difference between east and west is real. One possible

Fig. 5. Histograms of slope failure parameters for events in fjords in Norway and eastern Canada, and other limited areas such as harbours, tidal
flats etc. The vertical axis in the graphs shows the number of failures; n is the total number of failures represented in each histogram. When
extreme values were excluded (to increase the interpretability of the histogram), this is mentioned in the graph. The solid black lines represent
normal distributions with the same mean and standard deviation as the parameter presented in each histogram.

explanation is that the many small slope failures in the
western North Atlantic are associated with submarine
canyons (Booth et al., 1993; McAdoo et al., 2000),
since similar canyoned slopes are relatively rare in the

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
353
Fig. 5 (continued).

eastern North Atlantic (Weaver et al., 2000). It is also
possible that some of the groups of dsmallT landslides
mapped on the western North Atlantic margin actually
correspond to single landslide events with complex
headwalls. Such a headwall and slide scar complex
has clearly been mapped for the 1929 Grand Banks
landslide (Piper et al., 1999).
On both sides of the North Atlantic, a large number
of landslides initiate in water depths of 1000–1300 m
(Figs. 3f and 4g). This observation, first noticed in the
western North Atlantic by Booth et al. (1993), is
unexpected, because this depth range does not
correspond to the steepest part of the slope nor is it
related to any obvious sedimentological or deposi-
tional parameter (e.g., maximum sedimentation rate).
Information about the structure of the failed layers,
their sedimentology, and their geotechnical properties
might give further insight into the mechanisms
involved, but without these more detailed observa-

tions, it remains unclear why so many failures happen
at these water depths. Gas hydrates and possible
hydrate instability (Mienert et al., 2002) and/or
internal waves (Cacchione and Pratson, 2004; Cac-
chione et al., 2002) could play an important role in
destabilising sediments at these water depths, but
again much more data is required to prove their
involvement.
4.3. Correlations and dependencies

Tables 2–4 show the correlation coefficients of the
variables for landslides in the eastern and western
North Atlantic and in fjords. The number of volcanic
island landslides is too small to produce meaningful
values. Due to the skewed distribution of most
variables (as shown in the histograms), the commonly
applied Pearson correlation coefficient could not be
used. This coefficient is a measure of linear relation-

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
354

ship between two variables, and assumes the data to
be normally distributed (Davis, 1986), which is
clearly not the case here. Instead, Spearman’s rho
rank correlation coefficient was calculated, which

Fig. 6. Histograms of slope failure parameters for events on volcanic islands of the Canary and Hawaiian Islands. The Hawaiian Islands were
included in order to give a perspective overview over volcanic islands as such. The vertical axis in the graphs shows the number of failures; n is
the total number of failures represented in each histogram. The solid black lines represent normal distributions with the same mean and standard
deviation as the parameter presented in each histogram.

indicates if variables are positively or negatively (but
not necessarily linear!) related. It is stressed at this
point that only cases where the database contains a
value for both relevant parameters can be used for the

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
355
Fig. 6 (continued).

calculation. This often seriously limits the number of
pairs, and therefore as a result these are different from
the number of cases shown in the histograms. Some
variables clearly have a higher correlation than others.
Thus, they vary together, either in a positive or in a

with area and volume (Tables 2–4, Fig. 7a, b) or that
the headwall height correlates with the thickness of

with some landslide dimensions (although the number
of cases is not very high); this is not seen in the other
environments.
Several other correlations (or lacks of correlation)
can be picked from the correlation tables. Some of
these have been further explored using scatter plots
(Fig. 7a–h). In general, slope correlates poorly with

almost every other parameter (Tables 2–4). A scatter
plot of slope angle in source area against landslide
length shows only a weak, but inverse, correlation for
all geographic areas (Fig. 7c). Landslides occur on
slopes of virtually every angle, although the majority
occur on slopes between 28 and 208. Clearly, slope is a
poor indicator of susceptibility to landsliding. No
increase in landslide length (i.e., runout) is seen with
increasing slope angle. Counter intuitively; there is
even a suggestion that the longest runout landslides
occur on more gentle slopes. This conclusion is

supported by the plots of volume against slope angle,
which suggests that the largest landslides tend to be
associated with low slope angles (Fig. 7d, also see
Fig. 7a–c). This suggests that the influence of the
rheology of the failed material might be a key factor.
One possible interpretation is that small slope fail-
ures occurring on relatively steeper slopes involve
stiffer, less disintegrative, material (i.e., slump-type
failures). McAdoo et al. (2000) made a similar
observation. On the other hand, failures covering
vast areas on low slopes might consist of a softer
material and become more mobile (i.e., debris flow).
This might in turn relate to variation in depositional
processes on steep and low slopes. Several authors
have proposed that weak layers might be the source
of the more mobile material (O’Leary, 1991;
Haflidason et al., 2003, 2004). Combining this
observation with the correlations involving slope
angle it might be allowed to suggest that on any
given slope a failure consisting of stiffer material

Slope
angle in
deposition
area

Water
depth in
source
area

Thickness
of slope
failure
deposit

Thickness
of failed
section

Headwall
height

would not travel as far as a flow comprised of softer,
less consolidated sediment.
A plot of headwall height against slope angle
shows different trends for eastern North Atlantic
landslides compared to landslides in fjords. In the
eastern North Atlantic, headwalls of failures tend to be
high on low slope angles and decrease with higher
angles, whereas a weak but opposite trend seems to
characterise fjords (Fig. 7e). This may partly reflect
the spread of landslide sizes on the eastern North
Atlantic margin, since larger landslides in this
environment tend to have higher headwalls (Fig. 7f).
However, headwall height has little effect on the
volume of fjord landslides. Therefore, the possibility
that the difference in headwall height/slope angle
relationship between the two areas may reflect differ-
ences in geologic processes cannot be ruled out.
A comparison between the thickness of a landslide
deposit and the thickness of the failed section can give
a useful measure of the degree of disintegration of the

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
358

Fig. 7. Log–log scatter plots of selected failure parameters for slides in different tectonic environments. The number of cases used for the
parameters in these plots is identical with the ones shown in Tables 2–4.

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
359
Fig. 7 (continued).

landslide. Although we have few database entries
where both parameters are recorded, there appears to
be a significant difference in the behaviour of the
eastern North Atlantic and fjord landslides (Fig. 7g).
On the margin, there is a positive correlation between
deposit and failed section thickness, which perhaps
suggests that these are dominantly translational events
with limited disintegration and spreading of the
landslide mass. In contrast, in fjords, thicker failures
correlate with a reduction of deposit thickness,
suggesting that landslides within fjords are even more
disintegrative and spread relatively further than the
failure events on the open slope. This is also
supported by the correlation values in Tables 2–4. It

is unlikely that this could be due to the confined
geometry of the fjords (which should tend to reduce
runout and flow spreading), so it is more likely only to
reflect the nature of the sediments involved in the
landslide and the flow processes. For example, many
fjord landslides involve highly mobile quick clays,
which will contribute to disintegrative behaviour and
long runout (Longva et al., 2003).
An inverse correlation between the ratio of dtotal
height to runout distance (h/l)T and landslide vo-
lume, previously described in the literature (e.g.,
Hampton et al., 1996), fits well with the results found
for the western North Atlantic margin but not for
those on the eastern North Atlantic where h/l appears

V. Hu¨hnerbach, D.G. Masson / Marine Geology 213 (2004) 343–362
360

to show no systematic variation with volume (Fig.
7h). This may largely be due to the lack of small
events on the eastern North Atlantic margin, which
weakens the control on the slope of the correlation
line, since the values (and scatter of values) for large
landslides are similar for both western and eastern
North Atlantic.
The collated data set does not yet provide a
reasonable base for making assumptions of univer-
sal behaviour of slope failure. Many more gaps in
the incomplete data set would need to be filled
before any such conclusion could be reached.
However, the dobviousT correlations between length,
width, area cover and volume might support the
idea that many submarine slides share similar
characteristics. For example, the scatter plot repre-
senting length and width (Fig. 7i) suggests a
possible relationship between these parameters.
Although conclusions drawn from this point would
have to be taken with some caution, it would be
very interesting to prove if this relationship could
lead to some kind of predictions for future slope
failure behaviour.
The involvement of trigger mechanisms has been
mostly excluded in this discussion because there was
no clear picture of any dominating mechanism in the
data set. Possible trigger mechanisms which are, or
thought to be, most common, include earthquakes, gas
hydrates, tectonic movement, solifluction, internal
waves, sediment overload, erosion, sea-level change,
ground-/freshwater seepage and, especially in fjords,
human impact.
It is clear from our study that a much more
meaningful analysis could have been performed if
more modern high-resolution mapping data had been
available. Collecting high-resolution sidescan, multi-
beam and seismic data to get a complete picture of a
submarine landslide and its surrounding environment,
dimensions, surface and subsurface expression is a
necessity; not only for statistical analysis, but also to
give more insight in the processes involved in
landsliding. Geotechnical data from boreholes and
samples is likely to hold the key to understanding
landslide processes, but is rarely available. This is
sometimes both technically difficult and expensive to
obtain, although some such data exist already,
particularly in industry, which needs to be encouraged
to release it to the academic community. Initiatives

like COSTA are a good opportunity to bring industry
and scientists together and try to reach these aims.
5. Conclusions and observations

The unique COSTA landslide database contains
data from some 260 landslides on both margins of the
North Atlantic and adjacent seas. Despite the fact that
many database entries are incomplete, some observa-
tions and possible conclusions can be drawn from the
statistical analysis of the data:

!
Slope angle does not appear to influence the
occurrence of landslides; there is even a suggestion
that the largest landslides occur on the lowest
slopes.
!
The eastern North Atlantic is characterised by few
large slope failures, whereas the western North
Atlantic accommodates abundant small failures.
!
An unexpected peak in landslide headwall location
occurs at a water depth of about 1000–1300 m on
both sides of the North Atlantic suggesting a
specific sediment rheology (weak layers) being
prone to failure under certain environmental
conditions, such as internal waves or sediment
overloading.
!
The correlation between landslide length and width
could indicate a possible dpredictiveT behaviour.
!
Landslides
in
fjords
tend
to
be
largely
disintegrative.
Limitation of the database include:

!
The incomplete nature of many database entries,
due to survey limitations and/or missing parame-
ters in published documentation.
!
Inaccurate data and discrepancies due primarily to
survey limitations and survey coverage in different
environments.
!
Key parameters (e.g., geotechnical measurements
and sediment rheology) are rarely available.
